body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When using the following code:
```cython
from libcpp.algorithm cimport equal
from libcpp.vector cimport vector

cdef vector[int] a
equal(a.begin(), a.end(), a.begin(), a.end())
```

with this definition of equal:
```cython
    bool equal[InputIt1, InputIt2, BinPred](InputIt1 first1, InputIt1 last1, InputIt2 first2, BinPred pred) except +

    # ambiguous with previous overload
    #bool equal[InputIt1, InputIt2](InputIt1 first1, InputIt1 last1, InputIt2 first2, InputIt2 last2) except 
```

Cython generates the following code:
```cpp
std::equal<std::vector<int> ::iterator,std::vector<int> ::iterator,std::vector<int> ::iterator>(
    __pyx_v_4test_a.begin(), __pyx_v_4test_a.end(),
    __pyx_v_4test_a.begin(), __pyx_v_4test_a.end()
);
```
This fails to compile, since we specify three template arguments, while only two are available in the overload I would like to use.
However I do not understand why Cython even has to set these template types. Shouldn't it be enough to generate:

**Describe the solution you'd like**
When template types are already derived by cython it should be possible for C++ to do the same. So when calling them without template types it should be enough to generate:

```cpp
std::equal(
    __pyx_v_4test_a.begin(), __pyx_v_4test_a.end(),
    __pyx_v_4test_a.begin(), __pyx_v_4test_a.end()
);
```

This can however only be done when they are not specified, while for `func[int](arg)` it would still be required to generate the old code.



**Describe alternatives you've considered
In this specific case we could stop considering the argument type for the last argument using something like:
```
bool equal[InputIt1, InputIt2](InputIt1 first1, InputIt1 last1, InputIt2 first2, ...) except 
```

comment_data.body:
I don't think we should necessarily do it generally (I think the reason for it is to make sure that Cython is using the overload that Cython believes itself to be using) but an option to turn it off would be nice - there's quite a few cases like this where it would make things work better.

Perhaps

```
    bool equal[InputIt1, InputIt2, BinPred, Cython.dont_explicitly_specialize](InputIt1 first1, InputIt1 last1, InputIt2 first2, BinPred pred) except +
```

would work as a not-too-awful syntax?

title: [ENH] Do not specify template types when calling functions
